[et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ specialty=”on” _builder_version=”3.22.7″][et_pb_column type=”3_4″ specialty_columns=”3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”0px|||||”][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|600|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ text_orientation=”center” max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”|-5px||61px||” custom_padding=”|0px||||”]

From injury prevention, bodily preparation, and increased mental focus, a quality warm-up is vital. In this article we’ll dive into what makes a warm-up great and include some fun ideas you can use with your team.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ width=”100%” max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”|-38px||||”]

The Importance of An Effective Warm-Up

Warming up before a football match or training session is essential to prepare the body for activity and focus the mind for what lies ahead. Here’s a quick overview of some of the most important benefits of a proper warm-up:

  • Reduces the risk of injury
  • Increases the body’s range of motion
  • Increases body temperature
  • Activates the cardiovascular and respiratory systems
  • Improves mental focus

On a physiological level, a warm-up gradually increases heart rate and blood circulation so that the body’s cardiovascular system can transport and deliver the nutrients muscles need for football activities effectively. In addition by preparing the body steadily, acute injuries such as strains or pulls are much less likely to occur.

In terms of mental preparation, a quality warm-up provides an opportunity to clear the mind and focus on the task at hand. It effectively sets the tone for the upcoming practice or game. In this article we’ll go over seven ideas for effective, fun, and engaging warm-ups.

If you’re more of a video person, the video below highlights five extremely simple and effective warm-up ideas.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_video src=”https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nJ–ZDSIgG4&t=7s” _builder_version=”3.22.7″ width=”80%” width_tablet=”” width_phone=”100%” width_last_edited=”on|phone” max_width=”100%” module_alignment=”center”][/et_pb_video][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ width=”98.5%” max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”23px|-21px|25px|||”]

1. General Dynamic Warm-Up

In order to ensure that the body is adequately prepared for the impending work load, it’s vital that a warm-up includes similar movements to what the players will be doing in a match. Warm-ups that encompass a wide variety of movements and extend a player’s range of motion are especially effective. This can be accomplished by having players perform various different dynamic locomotions. A general dynamic warm-up can easily be administered by having players in two lines and performing these locomotions back and forth.

With that being said, dynamic locomotions can be incorporated into a wide range of different formats and warm-up activities and there are plenty of different movements to choose from. Here are some common ones:

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”23px||25px|||” custom_padding_tablet=”” custom_padding_phone=”0px||” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Dynamic Warm-Up Movements

  • Forward Jogging
  • Backward Jogging
  • Side Shuffles
  • Skipping With Backward Arm-circles
  • Backward Skipping
  • Sideways Skipping
  • Grapevine/Carioca
  • Sideways Jumping Jacks
  • High Kicks
  • Inside Touches
  • High Knees
  • Butt Kickers
  • Two Foot Jumps
  • Single Leg Hops

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”23px||25px|||” custom_margin_tablet=”-75px||” custom_margin_phone=”-76px||” custom_margin_last_edited=”on|desktop” custom_padding_tablet=”” custom_padding_phone=”0px||0px” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|tablet”]

  • Leap Frog
  • Forward Lunges
  • Backwards Lunges
  • Sideways Lunges
  • Lunges With A Twist
  • Knee To Chest Stretch
  • Quad Stretch
  • Toe Touches
  • Bear Crawls
  • Crab Walk
  • 50% Jog
  • 75% Run
  • 100% Sprint

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/General-Dynamic-Warm-Up.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/general-dynamic-warm-up/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ width=”70%” width_tablet=”” width_phone=”100%” width_last_edited=”on|phone” module_alignment=”center”][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″]

In this simple general dynamic warm-up variation players perform different locomotions in two lines.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

2. Practice Basic Technical Skills

Warming up can also provide a great opportunity for players to practice fundamental technical skills such as dribbling, trapping, and passing. Since a coach’s time with their players may be limited, incorporating technical skills into a warm-up is a great way to kill two birds with one stone and accelerate player development. Here’s a few warm-up ideas to help players practice the fundamentals:

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Speedy Dribbling Warm-Up

In the speedy dribbling warm-up players dribble through cone gates to practice maintaining control of the ball. Once players are warm, this exercise can easily be made into a competition by seeing which player can dribble through the most cones in a given amount of time.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Speedy-Dribbling-Warm-Up.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/speedy-dribbling-warm-up/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_padding=”||18px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Passing-Down-The-Field.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/passing-down-the-field/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Passing Down The Field

This simple partner passing warm-up allows players to work on passing fundamentals with minimal set up from the coach. Players just need a partner and a ball as they pass back and forth from one end to the other. This drill also works great with headers or volleys.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Juggle For Distance

Another drill requiring minimal set up, juggle for distance is a game where players in pairs juggle down the field, trying to keep the ball up for as long as possible. The team that makes it the furthest without the ball hitting the ground wins!

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Juggle-for-distance.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/juggle-for-distance/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_margin=”||18px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

3. Tag Games

Tag games can be a fun and competitive way to get players moving. They work especially well when trying to develop speed, agility, and quick reactions. Keep in mind players shouldn’t run full speed right at the begining of practice so performing some dynamic movements beforehand is a great way to ease into these activities.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

1v1 Tag

1v1 tag is a fun exercise where runners try to get to the other side without being tagged. The taggers typically start by sitting down or performing an exercise at the beginning so that the runner has a slight advantage. This encourages the runner to move as quickly as possible as soon as they start.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/1v1-Tag.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/1v1-tag/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_margin=”||15px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/5ce3cce149f8e-5ce3cce149f91Rock-Paper-Scissors-Tag-.png.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/rock-paper-scissors-tag/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_margin=”||5px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Rock, Paper, Scissors Tag

Another similar 1v1 tag variation, in rock, paper, scissors tag players first play rock, paper, scissors. The player who wins is the tagger and the player who loses tries to run across their own end line before being tagged.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_padding=”35px|||||”]

4. Relay Races

Relay races are another great way to get players moving at top speed in a fun and competitive environment. Relay races can incorporate different movements such as those used in a dynamic warm-up or be used with a ball to practice technical skills like dribbling and passing with pace.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Dribbling Relay

In this simple dribbling relay players dribble as fast as they can around the final cone and then back to their starting spot before sitting down to show that they have completed their leg of the relay. The first team to have all of their players sitting down wins!

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Dribbling-Relay.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/dribbling-relay-race/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Slalom-Dribble.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/slalom-dribbling-relay/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Slalom Dribbling Relay

Similar to the dribbling relay, in this variation players weave in and out of the cones to work on keeping close control of the ball.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”28px|||||”]

5. Rondo Drills

A rondo is a keep away style drill where one team with numerical superiority tries to keep possession while the other team tries to dispossess them.

‘Everything that goes on in a match, except shooting, you can do in a rondo. The competitive aspect, fighting to make space, what to do when in possession and what to do when you haven’t got the ball, how to play ‘one touch’ soccer, how to counteract the tight marking and how to win the ball back’ -Johan Cruyff

Many professional teams like to start training sessions and match warm-ups with some sort of basic rondo keep away variation. Most popular is the 4v2 rondo where four players in a circle have the ball against two defenders in the middle. If a defender wins the ball, they swap places with the player who lost it.

Since rondos are so effective to improve player’s reactions and touch, here are a few other great variations of rondo drills:

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”24px|||||” column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

4v2 Rondo With Dribble Retake

In this rondo variation each offensive player stays on one side of a square. If the defenders win the ball they have a 2v1 advantage as they try to score on one of the outside goals.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Rondo1.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/4v2-rondo-with-dribble-retake/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_padding=”||29px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/3-Team-Possession-Drill.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/3-team-possession-drill/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Three Team Possession Drill

The three team possession drill is a variation played with three teams, each of which starting in their own zone. The ball starts on one side and the team in possession tries to complete a certain number of passes in a row before sending the ball to the other side for a point. Meanwhile, the team in the middle sends two players in to try to win the ball back. If they manage to take the ball away, the team that lost it becomes the new team in the middle.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Find The Killer Pass

In find the killer pass, the team in possession gains their numerical supieriority through the inclusion of neutral players who play all time offense. The object of the game is to complete a given number of passes and then find a teammate in the middle for a point.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Find-The-Killer-Pass.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/find-the-killer-pass/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_padding=”||12px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_padding=”35px|||||”]

6. Mini Games

Small sided games can be a great way to mimic in game action on a smaller scale so that players can get lots of touches on the ball relative to what they would recieve during a full sided match. Taking this into account, mini games can be a great addition to a warm-up routine after a dynamic warm-up. Simply play 3v3, 4v4, or 5v5, or add some wrinkles to create a new variation like the exercise below.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Mini Goal Game With Neutrals

This small sided game variation is a fun take on the classic 4v4 where the team in possession can also pass to neutral players. This ensures that the attacking team always has an advatange for fast paced action and lots of goal scoring opportunities.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Mini-Goal-Game-With-Neutrals.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/mini-goal-game-with-neutrals/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_padding=”||27px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

7. Finishing

When players are sufficiently warm, spending some time to hone player’s finishing abilities can be a good idea. The exercises below function especially well to get strikers and goal keepers fully prepared and up to speed before a match.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner module_class=”reverse” _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

Rapid Fire Shooting Drill

The rapid fire shooting drill is an extremely simple finishing drill where players dribble out to the top of the penalty area, turn around, and have a go on goal. For quick action, the players on the opposite side can start dribbling forward as soon as the previous player reaches the top of the box.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/Rapid-Fire-Shooting-Drill.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/rapid-fire-shooting-drill/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_margin=”||25px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″ column_structure=”1_2,1_2″][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/05/3v2-To-Goal.png” url=”https://www.360player.com/blog/3v2-to-goal-shooting-drill/” url_new_window=”on” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ custom_margin=”||5px|||”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column_inner][et_pb_column_inner type=”1_2″ saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”rgba(47,50,54,0.8)” text_font_size=”18px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_2_font_size=”40px” header_2_line_height=”1.1em” custom_margin=”|||” text_font_size_tablet=”” text_font_size_phone=”” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet” text_line_height_tablet=”1.4em” text_line_height_phone=”” text_line_height_last_edited=”on|tablet” header_2_font_size_tablet=”30px” header_2_font_size_phone=”” header_2_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

3v2 To Goal

3v2 to goal is a great way for players to work on finishing because the offensive team outnumber the defenders. With this in mind, there should always be an open player to get off a quality shot.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][et_pb_row_inner _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column_inner saved_specialty_column_type=”3_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”52px|||||” custom_padding=”46px|||||”]

More Resources For Football Warm-Ups

If you’d like more warm-up ideas you can check out all of our favorite warm-up drills here. We constantly add new exercises to our library and hope that you find these resources helpful.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column_inner][/et_pb_row_inner][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_sidebar orientation=”right” _builder_version=”3.22.7″][/et_pb_sidebar][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″]

excerpt.rendered: An effective warm-up is important for many reasons from injury prevention, bodily preparation, and increased mental focus.
